being sworn and examined before us, the major part of the commissioners, Mr. Burrow and Mr. Burrell, upon oath, saith, that the entry he made, one hundred and fourteen, ledger of bills, were given for washing. The credit side, goods sold to a person of the name of Moranda, was made up; about the time they were made the greater part were sold by my brother, James, to Signora Moranda. She is an Opera lady, and lives in the Haymarket. I believe her to be thirty years of age and upwards. The last articles were sold by myself. The entry,
Edward James
, was entered as a real transactions; and much about the same time they bear date,
Edward James
. I do not think there are any regular entries made. He is about thirty years of age. The articles, seventy-three pounds, were taken away in an hackney coach, in day time. My brother, James, assisted in packing them up. They consisted of various articles of jewellery. Baroness Menkwitz lives in Downing-street. She actually owes me what appears in the books. When did you see the Baroness. In the early part of February I saw her at the West end of the town. She took the suit of pearls herself. All the goods in the said account were delivered to her in my shop.
John Shehey
was a wine and brandy merchant in Smithfield. He came to my shop for the goods. He is now in the Fleet. The account of Count Holmar is a true and correct account. The goods sold in November last. I delivered them to him myself. The bullion consisted of doubloons, some India pieces, and some coin. The bullion was sold at different times. Halliday became a bankrupt in the Fleet. The goods were sold to Halliday when he lived in Bell Savage-yard, in the city. The eleventh leaf is written by the boy. The baroness is written by my brother, James.
Q. to Mr. Powis. You have examined the books carefully - A. I have.

Q. Did you ask him any questions about certain goods that he had charged, which you thought he had not rightly charged - A. I have asked him questions upon all these accompts which I suspected. I pointed out two accounts to him, and particular; Halliday was one, the other Shehey. I pointed out the absurdity, to shew him, that he could have credited such a man as Halliday; he must know his real situation in life. I remonstrated with him how he could have trusted such a man as that. At that time he trusted him he had been recently liberated from the Rules of the Fleet. At the time the bankrupt credited him, Halliday had no means of living. Speaking to him one time upon that, he said, you are the only man who knows any thing respecting Halliday or Shehey; if you remain quiet you shall have nothing to complain of. I told him, it would be better for him to tell the truth. After that he said, he believed the account of Halliday and Shehey to be fabricated, but said he, it was all his, William and Nugent's doing: he was ill at the time. He then told me, if I would remain his friend, and would not oppose his certificate, that he should have at command, in a short time, five or six thousand pounds. I said, why, you have not done the trick to deep as that, and asked him to explain himself. He said, he had it in his power to marry a woman of that property.
Q. With respect to the enquiry of Bond; you have examined the books - A. I have.
Q. Did you find any articles charged to these persons, which by these books you find to have come in afterwards - A. I do.

Q. State the articles - A. It is in the account of James. The articles are two trunks booked to him in November last charged three pounds eight shillings. He said, he had them of Mr. Briant, Ludgate-hill. I pointed out to him the absurdity that he had not them in his possession until the 26th of that month. He said, it might be a mistake in the date. He was conscious the account of James was correct, although it was not his own making. He was ill a bed at the time.

Q. Now, I ask you, sir, what is the deficiency upon the estate - A. The deficiency, admitting these debts to be just, amounts to between two and three thousand pounds, and if they are not just they amount to five.

Mr. Andrews. What was the amount of your debt against
John Folkard
- A. Ninety-nine pounds thirteen shillings.

Q. Do you know what business James Folkard was - A. He was shopman to his brother,
John Folkard
.

Q. Do you know whether James was present when Bond proved his debt - A. No, I am sure he was not.
William Folkard
was there, but not John.

Q. On the 25th of November here is an entry in the book of James. Do you know the hand-writing of
James Folkard
- A. I believe it to be his. I have seen him write. In addition, he admitted it to be his. I asked
James Folkard
, whose hand-writing was this. He said, his; and that the Baroness Minkwitz had called in November 1811.

JOHN ROBINSON
. Q. At the time of this commission you were a creditor - A. Yes, to
John Folkard
to about one hundred and thirty pounds, me and my partner.
BARONESS MINKWITZ. Q. Where did you reside in the month of February last - A.In Fleet-lane, at Mr. Bond's house. I had lodged there between four and five months. I came there in October last.
Q. Were you acquainted at that time with the prisoner, Nugent - A. Yes. I have known him many years.
Q. Do you know Jacob Grick - A. Yes.

Q. On the 13th of February do you recollect any of the five persons being at your lodgings, either Nugent or the Folkards - A. I cannot be sure to the day. On the Thursday, Nugent, and the other gentleman. He said, his name was
John Folkard
. When they came I was below stairs.
Q. Was you landlord at home at that time - A. I cannot be sure that Mr. Bond was at home.

Q. Did you afterwards go up stairs - A. Yes, the parlour and street door was open. I saw them come in. They said, how do you do, Baroness. I followed them up stairs.
John Folkard
was a stranger to me. Nugent first spoke to me. He set himself down. He said, how do you do: he had introduced a friend of his. He told me his name. He said, did I ever hear him mention his friend Folkard. I said, not as I recollected: He then said, he came there. Some enemies of Mr. Folkard had struck a docket against him. I said, have they? He said, yes; we want to get over, on Monday, a trifle of business. I come to ask you, if Mr. Grick, and the man at your house, would come forward and do us a favour.

COURT. He did not mention that you were to take part in it - A. Not at the time. I said, what is it? He said, next Monday they were to choose assignees, and they wanted to have their own friends chosen for assignees. Mr. Grick was then sitting in my room, by the fire side. Mr. Grick was in the room before Nugent and Folkard came. Nugent said, do you think the young man will go. That was Grick, to go and prove under the commission. I said, I did not know. Mr. Nugent then said, do you think the man of the house will do it; I said, I did not know; you had better ask him; you had better ask him yourself. Nugent then explained the business to Grick. Grick said he would do it if there was no harm in it. I went down and asked Mrs. Bond. Mr. Nugent said, he would have a dinner and a one-pound note. Mrs. Bond said, if it was to hail any body her husband should not go. The way it was to be done Mr. Folkard was to give bills.
Q. Was that the way Folkard or Nugent explained it - A. They both explained it was to be done that way. Mr. Folkard was to give bills to Grick and Bond.
Q. What were these bills to be for - A. That Mr. Folkard owed Grick and Bond so much money, to go and prove them at Guildhall on the Monday.
Q. Had Nugent said, at that time, whether he had applied to some of his own friends - A. Yes; he said he had some of his own friends; he did not say how many; but he wanted five or six more.

Q. What were you to have - A. I was to have a one-pound note and a black set of ornaments, and I was to persuade Grick and Bond to do this, and get any body else I could persuade to go and swear a debt.

Q. On the next day did you see Nugent again - A. Nugent went, and said, he would come the next day. That was Friday. On the Friday he came, and brought
William Folkard
with him. I had never spoken to
William Folkard
in my life. I had seen him at a trial, in a Court. Nugent introduced him as usual; here is a friend of mine, who is a brother to the gentleman that was here before. He said, he is a very good friend to prisoners; his name was Folkard. I asked
William Folkard
if he had had brought the ear-rings. He said, I should have them; his brother and Nugent were to come the next day, and to bring them in his pocket, with the bills. I told Nugent I should not be at home on the Saturday. Then he said he would call on the Sunday. On the Sunday afternoon I, Mr. Bond, Mrs. Bond, and Mr. Grick, we all went out to avoid them.
Q. When you came home in the evening did you learn that any body had been looking after you - A. Yes, on the evening, when we returned about eleven o'clock I received that note.
Q. Whose hand-writing is that note - A. Mr. Nugent's. (Read.)
="My dear Baroness, I am waiting with great anxiety, at the Bell, in the Old Bailey, where I shall stay until eleven o'clock.
Yours, T. N.="

Q.Shortly after you had been at home did Nugent and Folkard come to your house - A. After the little girl gave me the note I opened it, and read it, and gave it to Mr. Bond, and while I was sitting there Nugent and Folkard came into the house, and went up into my room. Nugent said, how do you do, and put a bit of paper into my hand. That was a one-pound note. I told him I did not think that Bond and Grick wished to go to-morrow to Guildhall. Nugent said, let me speak to them. Bond and Grick came up stairs. He began explaining the business to Bond and Grick in my hearing. He said, it was nothing but just to go to Guildhall, and to say that Mr.
John Folkard
owed him so much money. They sent out for something to drink.
William Folkard
took his pocket-book out, and took some stamp bills out. He wrote on paper for how much the bills should be drawn.

Q. Did Nugent take the bills up and look at them. Do you recollect who it was that wrote the bills on the stamp paper - A. Mr. Nugent. I will not be sure which it was. Nugent looked at it. When the bills were wrote out, he said, Bill is it all right.
William Folkard
said, what? Nugent said, are they old stamps. William Folkard said, yes, he had taken care of that. I asked him, why they ought to be old. Nugent said, it would not be right to have their bills drawn upon a new stamp at such a time, as the Stamp-office gentlemen altered. their marks every month.
Q. Was there any bill drawn upon Bond or Grick - A. One was filled for Bond and one for Grick.

Q. Were there any that were not filled up given to you - A. Yes, three stamp bills; they were accepted by Folkard, in blanks. I was to try to get some of my acquaintance to fill them up, and come to Guildhall on Monday to prove them.

Q. Were you acquainted with a painter and glazier in Bloomsbury - A. Yes, a Mr. Priest, in High-street, Bloomsbury. I was to make him come and prove on Monday. I applied to Mr. Priest. I was desired to apply to him. He was to prove to the amount of two hundred and fifty pounds. I went to Mr. Priest, and shewed him the black acceptance, and told him he was to go and prove on Monday morning. He refused to do it.

Q. After they left you when did they call again - A. About eleven o'clock on the Monday they called again. Nugent called in an hackney coach, and
William Folkard
with him. Nugent said, he would take us in the coach to the Butler's Head in Bell-alley, Coleman-street. We were to meet John, and then, at twelve o'clock, to meet the creditors. We were to meet
John Folkard
, to get what was promised, the one-pound note and the ear-rings, and such things. I told him I would not go with him, but I would go afterwards. I went there with Grick.

Q. Did Bond accompany you - A. No. We went to the Butler's Head, in Bell-alley. I asked for Nugent. That was about eleven in the day. Nugent had been there. They could not accommodate him with a room. He had gone to the White Bear, in London Wall. We went to the White Bear. There were several people up stairs. Nugent was not directly there.
William Folkard
and Humphreys were at that house. I did not see
John Folkard
at that house.

Q. Did you see Kelly there - A. Yes, and I heard a man called by the name of Shehey there. I gave
William Folkard
the blank acceptances. I said, I could not get any more. I left them all there, and I went home.
Q. Where were they to go from thence - A. To Guildhall.

COURT. Was it said so at that meeting - A. Yes, after I came home. Grick came home in about an hour after, and in the afternoon Nugent and
James Folkard
called on me at my house. Nugent said, it is all over; we have lost the day. I did not know
James Folkard
before. Nugent said, the money was all thrown away.

Q. On the next day which of the parties did you see - A. James and
William Folkard
. William Folkard said, as they had not got assignees they must make the books up, as they had not got their own friends for assignees. I turned to William, and did not wish to speak before this young man. He said, it was all right, it was his brother, James. He told me then he must put down that I owed so much money to John.

Q. Did you owe the money - A. No. He told me he would call with Nugent and arrange it. James said, as you are the lady that has been in our shop I should have known you by the description of our young man.
Q. Were you a prisoner at this time in the rules of the Fleet - A. I was not. I lodged in Fleet-lane. I paid six shillings a week.

Q. Well, he said that Nugent and he would call and arrange it. Did Nugent afterwards call with William - A. Yes. He mentioned the Countess Holmar. I told him, she was gone abroad. He sold me he would be much obliged to me if I would find out when she went abroad, and when her husband went abroad.

Q. Where had her husband been before she went abroad - A. In the King's Bench prison, and he would give half-a-crown to enquire when the Count left the King's Bench prison, to find out the exact day, and how he spelt his name. I sent Mr. Bond over. When Bond returned he gave me a bit of paper with something on it. I gave it to Nugent and
William Folkard
. I read it. It was the time when the Count left the King's Bench, and how he spelt his name.
Q. Was any enquiry made where the Count lived - A. Yes. I told him she lived in Sloane-street, and the last time in Downing-street.

Q. Were you acquainted with Madam Moranda - Yes, she was an opera singer. Nugent asked me what her name was. She had lodged with me when I lived in St. James's. Nugent had seen her there. I told him I did not know where she lived now. Folkard said, he would book her down some things that she owed him.

Q. Do you mean owing him - A. No, his brother, John. I said, he might do it. I said, before you have been making fictitious bills, and now you are making debts. William said, they must make their accounts up.

Q. Did you ask him why this was - A. Yes. I said, first you make people say you are indebted to them, and now you want people that do not owe you any thing, to put down that they do. He said, they must balance the accounts. After that, William came on a Monday. I said to William, are you going to think of me? What are you going to book me down. He said, I must book you down a handsome necklace, and other things. He said, if I wanted to go to the Opera, and wanted a necklace, I should have it lent me.

Q. In the month of March do you recollect seeing any of them - A. Yes, I saw them all very often.
William Folkard
called on me one morning. Mr. Grick was with me. He asked me if I had seen Nugent. I told him, no, not this morning. He said, he wanted some money, if I knew where to get him some. He took out some strings of pearls. I asked him, how much he wanted on them. I saw a necklace. I said, is that necklace put down to me. He said, he did not know, I must ask his brother, John.

Q. Look at them writings, and tell me whether you know the hand-writing; they are two letters: who wrote them - A. John Folkard : I saw him write them in Mr. Bond's parlour, and both at the same time. Mrs. and Mr. Bond, and Mr. Grick, were there at the time.

Q. Did you see them papers - A. Yes; they were written at the same time the letters were. They are purporting to be bills of Bond, and Grick, and myself. They were written by
John Folkard
, in the presence of Bond, and his wife, and Grick, in Bond's house.

Q. Before these letters were written had you seen the assignees - A. Yes; they had been repeatedly to Bond, and threatened him to take him up, unless Bond could account how the debt accrued. The assignees did not know me then.
COURT. Were these letters written after the assignees threatened to take up Bond - A. Yes.
Q. Whose hand-writing are they - A. John Folkard 's.
Mr. Knapp. Did you ever give the account that you have to day until the assigness threatened to take up Bond - A. No.

Q. Did you apprehend, yourself, that any ill consequence would happen to you if you did not make that confession - A. I told
William Folkard
that he must come and appease the assigness; unless he would tell the truth I would.
Q. How long have you been in England - A. Twenty years.
Q. Your husband has been sent out of the country as an alien - A. Yes.
Q. You came here in custody - A. Yes, and I am to be sent out of the country as an alien.
Q. Have you been in custody - A. Yes, I have been in the Fleet.
Q. When was the first time that the assignees applied to you - A. The assignees never applied to me. I told Mr. Powis, myself, the truth.

GEORGE PREEST
. Q. Where do you live - A. No. 20, High-street, Bloomsbury-market.
Q. Do you remember the Baroness Minkwitz making any application to you in February last - A. Yes.

Q. Did she produce to you any paper - A. Yes, a blank stamp. I did not see any hand-writing at all on it. It laid on the table. She wanted me to go in a coach with her to a person in the Surry-road, to draw upon him for a sum of money.
Q. Did she mention the name - A. I cannot say that she did. She wanted me to go. I immediately refused. and she went away.
Mr. Andrews. Had you known her before - A.Yes; I was in a lock-up-house with her.

JAMES BOND. Q. In the month of February last where did you live - A. At 21, Fleet-lane. I am, what is called in our trade, a boot-foot-maker. I work for shops. The Baroness Menkwitz lodged in my house.
Q. Do you remember, in February last, the Baroness making any application to you respecting going to Guildhall - A. She did.
Q. Did you understand that some application was made for that purpose on the Sunday - A. I did.
Q. What time did you go out - A. About half past ten o'clock, or later.

Q. Upon your coming home together was any thing given to her - A. Yes, by the servant girl; there was a note, and shortly after that Thomas Nugent,
William Folkard
, and
John Folkard
came, and went into the one pair room, which was occupied by the Baroness.

Q. After they had gone up did any body come down to you - A. I cannot positively say. I rather think Nugent did, and I was asked, would I undertake to take a bill, and present it at Guildhall the following day.

Q. For what purpose - A. There was no specific purpose mentioned to me. I was to take the bill, and present it to persons at Guildhall. I did not enquire. It was a business I had no knowledge of at that time. I understood then that John Folkard was a bankrupt.
Q. Was any thing offered you - A. That I should be paid for my days work, and to have a dinner. I was to receive a pound note.
Q. Was Grick in your house - A. Yes, part of the time.
Q. While you were in the room was any thing written - A. There was the bill that I had, was written, and I believe another. The other was for Grick. I never saw the Folkards before that time.

JOHN DAVID
KELLLY. Q.You are clerk to Mr. Harmer. Did you serve a copy of that notice on the prisoner, Nugent - A. On Nugent, and on the Folkards, and their two attorneys.
(Read.)
Q. to Mr. Bond. Did you sign your name to the bill as drawer - A. I did.

Q. Was your bill accepted by
John Folkard
- A. It was accepted by
John Folkard
. I did not see him write it. There was an appointment made to meet at Butler's Head, Bell-alley, in Coleman-street. I went there the next day. I believe I went there by myself, others followed. When I got there I saw a person of the name of Shehey. From there we adjourned to the White Bear. I cannot say that Shehey was there. We went to the White Bear, London Wall. I saw
John Folkard
, Nugent, and Kelly, and a many others. I cannot say particularly whom: there was a number. The first thing that we thought of was, to provide something to eat. I went to Guildhall with Grick. There I saw the same persons as I saw at the White Bear. We did not all go together. I saw
William Folkard
there, not John. I saw
William Kelly
and Grick there. I believe I saw Humphreys there.

Q. Did you see Humpreys at the White Bear before you went to Guildhall - A. I think he was there. When I got to Guildhall, I proved my bill, and Grick did, and Kelly, and others did, as far as I saw. When I returned to the White Bear, I gave back the note I had received of Nugent. He called me out into another room. I there gave it him.

Q. After that did you tell
John Folkard
that Mr. Powis, the assignee, had called upon you - A. I did. Upon that
John Folkard
wrote this bill for me. I was to give this bill to Mr. Powis.
(Bill read.)

Q. Had you ever fold
John Folkard
any shoes or boots, as specified in that bill - A. No, I had not.
Q. Who was present at the time he wrote that account - A. I believe the Baroness was, and Grick, and this letter was written at the same time, to shew Mr. Powis.
(Letter read.)
Mr. Knapp. What are you - A. A boot-foot-maker.
Q. A housekeeper - A. I was at that time.
Q. And at this time, knowing yourself to much distressed, you went to Guildhall; you had no thought of committing perjury - A. I do not say but what I committed perjury.
Q. Which is the truth; that which you chose to swear before this - A. What I have said now is the truth.
Q. You were taken up, were you not - A. No, I was only threatened to be taken up.
Q. Then you turned cat in pan, and gave this account to save yourself.

Q. What was the rent that the Baroness paid you - A. She was to pay me the rent of the house, if I would let her carry on the business of selling coals. On her being taken up I lost five months rent, which was fourteen shillings and sixpence a week.
Q. You were quite ruined - A. I was.
COURT. You, in consequence of your losing five months rent, which was fourteen shillings and sixpence a week, you were quite ruined - A. I was.

JACOB GRICK
. Q. In the month of February last where did you live - A. In Fleet-lane, at Mr. Bond's.
Q. What are you by business - A. I was formerly a clerk. I was then living in the rules of the Fleet to avoid being arrested.

Q. Do you remember being in Baroness Menkwitz's room when Nugent called there - A. I recollect his calling there in the month of February. He first talked privately to her. I heard my name mentioned between them; then Nugent mentioned a bankruptcy of
John Folkard
; that he had spent a good deal of money; they wished for friends to get him through. Nugent wished me to take a bill, to go to Guildhall with, to prove under the bankruptcy, to get him through. He said he would pay me for my trouble. At last I agreed to do it. He appointed to meet me on the Sunday. I went out to avoid it, and when I came home I saw the two Folkards and Nugent in the room with Bond.

Q. Were any stamps produced, and bills drawn - A. Yes; William Folkard produced them; some
William Folkard
wrote, and some Nugent wrote. I wrote one myself; John Folkard accepted it, and he accepted Bond's, and he accepted one in black ink; he gave that to the Baroness to get another person.

Q. Do you remember any thing being said about these stamps - A. Nugent asked
William Folkard
if the stamps were all right. He answered, yes, they were all right; they were old stamps. Nugent said, it was not proper that bills so far back should be upon new stamps. On the next day I went to the Butler's Head;
William Folkard
came out and told us there was no room there. He took us to the White Bear. I saw
John Folkard
there. Nugent came afterwards. Bond, Shehey, and Kelly were there, and before we went to Guildhall the bills were arrayed and looked to by
William Folkard
, to see that they were all right.

Q. Did you go to Guildhall - A. I did, and proved the debt. After that I went back to the White Bear with Bond. I then saw Nugent and the other parties there, John and
William Folkard
. Nugent took the bills of me and Bond. He gave me a one-pound note.
Q. Afterwards did Mr. Powis, the assignee, come and make enquiry about your debt - A. I saw Mr. Powis at Bond's.

Q. After Mr. Powis came and questioned you about your debt, do you remember John Folkard came and wrote any papers for you - A. He wrote that paper for me in case Mr. Powis came there again. I asked John Folkard what I was to do about the business. He said, he would give me an account, and at the same time he wrote Mr. Bond's.
(Read.)

="
John Folkard
to
Jacob Grick
.
4 doubloons, - 19 l.
By dollars and coin - 15 l.="

Q. to Grick. Had you ever sold him any bullion - A. No, I was as poor as a man could be. Two or three days after we had been to Guildhall,
John Folkard
came to the Baroness, and enquired after names of persons that the Baroness knew; they wished to have some names of the Baroness's friends to book debts down to. They enquired after Signor Moranda, Count Holmar, and another Baron. They wished to have debts booked to them to make the books up. They said, they were to be persons that had gone out of the country. Nugent and Folkard said so. They called some one after upon the Baroness, and produced a necklace. They asked the Baroness, where they could pledge them. She recommended them to Parker's, in Fleet-street.

Q. Last night did you come to the house of Mr. Harmer for the purpose of giving information - A. I did. I met
William Folkard
in Fetter-lane. He asked me how I did. I told him the time was coming on. He asked me whether I was subpoened. I said, yes; I was very sorry for it. He asked me to go to Mr. Morley, the attorney, in Fleet-market.
Mr. Andrews. Who was your master when you were a clerk - A. Messrs. Hoffman and Co. of the Crescent, in the Minories.
Q. When you lived in Bond's house how many rooms did you and the Baroness occupy - A. There were two bed rooms between us.
Q. When the Baroness walked Fleet-street did you accompany her - A. I do not understand you.
Q.How long did you live together - A. Not quite a year.
Q. Are you friends now - A. We are not. I intend to go abroad of my own will. I certainly dislike her.

HANNAH BALDWIN
. Q. You keep the White Bear, London-wall - A. Yes.

Q. Do you remember on Monday, in February last, any persons being at your house - A. I do. I recollect my husband being ill at that time. Bond came and asked me if I had any room to accommodate them for refreshment. There were there four or five men. I noticed none.

SARAH WARNECK
. Q. You lived as servant with the Baroness in February last - A. Yes.

Q. Do you recollect on the Sunday, shortly after you were there, your mistress and Mrs. Bond going out - A. Yes, and they came home in the evening about eleven o'clock. Before they came home, Mr. Nugent and the two Folkards called and left a note. They said, they should call again. Mr. Nugent gave me the note. I gave it to my mistress. After my mistress came, Nugent and the two Folkards came. They went into my mistres's room. Some liquor was sent for. One of the Folkards was writing on paper. There was something like a stamp upon it. I do not know one of the Folkards from the other.
JOB POPE. I keep a green-grocer's shop, in Greek-street, Red-lion-square.

Q. Did the prisoner Nugent live in your house - A. He did, about a twelvemonth ago last August. At the time he was with me he was very poor. He has borrowed one, two, and three shillings of me. He had a wife and one child.

JONATHAN JOHNSON
. I am a victualler.

Q. Do you know Nugent - A. Yes, for about a twelvemonth. He got in my debt for porter about thirteen shillings. He paid me five shillings off. He said, he would call and pay the remainder. He never did.
JOHN NAARY. I am a dealer in coals. Nugent lived opposite of me. He is in debt five shillings and sixpence to me now for a sack of coals.

CATHERINE MORANDA. Q. Before the month of January last did you know
John Folkard
, who lived in Blackfriars-road, a silversmith - A. I do not know any thing about him. I never received any goods or bill of him.
Q. The charge is one hundred and sixty pounds nine shillings, for different articles - A. I never had any goods of him, nor never had any conversation with the Baroness about Mr. Folkard.
COURT. The counsel gives up the prosecution against Humphreys and James Folkard.

HUMPHREYS,
NOT GUILTY .

JAMES FOLKARD
,
NOT GUILTY .

JOHN FOLKARD
,
GUILTY .

Confined Two Years in Newgate , and to
stand in and upon the Pillory twice within that time, for the space of One Hour each time .

WILLIAM FOLKARD
,
GUILTY .

Confined in Newgate One Year , and to
stand in and upon the Pillory once during that time for One Hour .

NUGENT,
GUILTY .

Confined Eighteen Months in Newgate , and to
stand in and upon the Pillory once during that time for One Hour .
London jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

838.
HARRIET ROBERTS
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 29th of July , a pewter quart pot, value 20 d. and one pint pot, value 10 d. the property of
Ann Turner
.

ANN TURNER
. I keep a public-house in Queen Ann-street West
. I lost a quart and a pint pot. A young man brought the prisoner in to me, with the property in her apron.

THOMAS WIGGENS
. I am a bell-hanger. I was coming down Queen Ann-street; a gentleman told me he saw the prisoner take the pots from a door. I followed her, and took her to Mrs. Turner, and took the pots out of her apron. These are the pots.
Mrs. Turner. They are my pots.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in a little trouble. I picked them up. I did not know what I was doing of.
GUILTY , aged 47.

Confined One Year in the House of Correction , and
fined 1 s.
First Middlesex jury, before Mr. Recorder.

839.
SARAH GEORGE
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 2d of August , two tea-spoons, value 3 s. the property of
Barnard Gleed
.

BARNARD GLEED
. I am an officer. I keep an iron-shop . On Sunday, the 2d of August, my street door was open to let light in the shop while we were at breakfast. I went backwards, into the yard, and when I returned I found the spoons gone off the table. I found one of my spoons at Mr. Cotton's, a pawnbroker. I told him, if the woman came to take out the spoon, to stop her, and send for me. He did, and I took her in custody. This is the spoon. It is mine.
Prisoner's Defence. I pledged the spoon at Mr. Cotton's. The person that worked with me gave me the spoon.
GUILTY , aged 28.

Confined Six Months in the House of Correction , and
fined 1 s.
First Middlesex jury, before Mr. Recorder.

840.
WILLIAM GROVES
and
CHARLES DAVIS
were indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 1st of September , a time-piece, value 1 l. the property of
William Fradgley
.

WILLIAM FRADGLEY
. I live in Orchard-place, Kingsland-road.

JOHN CHAMBERS
. I have a stall in Orchard-place. The prisoners came and asked me the way to Shoreditch church. I directed them the road, and instead of their going the way that I told them, they turned down Philip-street. A little time after a lady came and looked down Philip-street: she said, there they run. She said, she had lost a time-piece. I gave the alarm of, stop thief. They both went into a garden, and from there into a privy. I went into the privy, and took Davis into custody. The lady picked up the time-piece.
- BARRETT. I pulled Groves out of the privy.
Prosecutor. This is the time-piece. It is mine. My wife picked it up. She is not here.
Groves said nothing in his defence.
Davis's Defence. I am innocent of the crime I am charged with.
GROVES, GUILTY, aged 23.
DAVIS, GUILTY, aged 19.

Judgment respited
.
First Middlesex jury, before Mr. Recorder.

841.
NATHANIEL SCOTT
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 8th of September , a great coat, value 5 s. the property of
Joseph Maskell
.

JOSEPH MASKELL
. I live in Barrow's-buildings, over Blackfriars-road. I am an hackney coachman .

Q. Did you lose a great coat - A. Yes, from my hackney coach. My coach was in Bridge-street
, with my great coat in it. About half past two I missed it. I had seen it in the coach about ten minutes before. I was in the house at dinner when the coat was taken. There was an alarm, and I found the man in custody, and the great coat with them. I know the coat to be mine. It is worth five shillings.

PETER LONG. I am an hackney coachman. I was on the stand in Bridge-street. Maskell's coach was next to mine. I was sitting on the box. A man gave me information. He told me to run up the street, I should catch the man with the coat. I ran up Union-street, towards Apothecaries-hall, and then to St. Andrew's-hill. I saw the prisoner with the coat under his arm. I laid hold of him, and brought him back, and delivered him up, with the coat, to Townshend, the officer.
WILLIAM TOWNSHEND. I am the constable of Bridewell hospital. The coat and the prisoner was delivered to me. This is the coat.
Prosecutor. It is my coat.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw the coat down by the horses heels. I picked it up. That goods man came and took me in Union-street.
The prisoner called two witnesses, who gave him a good character.
GUILTY, aged 36.

Judgment respited
.
London jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

842.
ELIZABETH BROWN
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 6th of July , two pair of sheets, value 2 l. the property of
William Wilson
.

MARIA WILSON
. I am the wife of
William Wilson
. My husband keeps the Three Pigeons and Stars, in Hatfield-street, Goswell-street, St. Luke's
. The prisoner was a lodger in my house. I lost two pair of sheets. On the 6th of July I missed them. The prisoner lived up two pair of stairs in my house. She came to us as a married woman. She cohabited with a man we supposed to be her husband.
Q. Had the man the same access to the house as the woman - A. Just the same. On the 6th of July I saw the prisoner going out with a bundle, between eleven and twelve o'clock.

Q. How lately before had you seen the sheets - A. At ten o'clock the sheets were safe. One pair of sheets were in the next room to where the prisoner lodged. She lodged in a two pair of stairs room. The other pair were in the club room. The door was locked, but I had left the key in the door.
Q. What was the value of these sheets - A. Two pounds.
Q. At what time did the man go out to work - A. At five o'clock in the morning. He was not at home that day after I saw her go out with the parcel.

Q. You saw her go out with a parcel - A. Yes, I did. She stopped, and had a glass of gin at the bar . I did not suspect her then. It was large enough to have contained these articles. It was covered over with an apron. About twelve o'clock that day I went up stairs and missed the sheets. She did not return to my house. On the next morning she was apprehended.

WILLIAM MATTING
. I am a constable. On the 7th of July I apprehended the prisoner, between nine and ten o'clock. She was sitting at a public-house door . I took her to Mrs. Wilson's, and searched her. I found upon her this houswife with three duplicates in it. I went to the pawnbroker, and discovered the sheets.

THOMAS DAVIS
. I am a pawnbroker in Brick-lane, Old-street. The prisoner pawned two blankets with me.
Q. That is not in this charge .

ROBERT UPSALL
. I am a servant to Mr. Williamson, 30, Barbican. On the 6th of July the prisoner pawned a pair of sheets, with me. I advanced five shillings and sixpence upon them.

JAMES HARRISON
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Read, pawnbroker, Redcross-street. I produce a pair of sheets pawned at our house. I do not know the person of the prisoner.
Prosecutrix. They are my property.
Prisoner's Defence. I pledged a pair of sheets and a pair of blankets.
GUILTY , aged 33.

Confined Six Months in the House of Correction , and
fined 1 s.
First Middlesex jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.
